title: Shopify hits 1 million merchants, but posts loss as it spends to boost network
text:
Shopify reported that it now has more than one million merchants on its e-commerce platform, which was cause for celebration among executives in a quarter where overall profitability was down by increased costs.

Shopify reported third-quarter revenue of US$390.9 million, a 45 per cent year-over-year increase, but that rate of growth represents a slowdown from previous years when the company would see revenue climbing by upwards of 70 per cent.

The company reported an operating loss of US$35.7 million for the quarter.

Shares were down 4 per cent in morning trading.

The past few months have been busy for Shopify, with the US$450 million acquisition of 6 River Systems, a robotics company that will support the Shopify move to build a fulfillment network of warehousing and shipping in the United States.

On the earnings call with analysts, chief financial officer Amy Shapiro signalled that as the Shopify Fulfillment Network gets up and running towards the end of the year, it’ll likely put a dent in the company’s overall gross margin, as the company spends money to ramp up the new line of business.

The announcement of one million merchants using Shopify was a surprise, as the company normally only updates its merchant count in February at the end of their fiscal year.

Speaking to analysts at the end of the earnings call, CEO Tobi Lutke got reflective about the milestone.

“Roughly around this time 15 years ago, I launched store No. 1,” he said.

“This is kind of blowing my mind right now.”

Lutke said the software as a service business model has been powerful for Shopify, building a subscriber base and continually improving the product in order to keep those merchants happy.

“I had an investor who ended up not investing because they told me that the worldwide market for online stores was about 40,000 stores,” Lutke said.

“So it’s just amazing to zoom out and see what happened, how many people are building their businesses, from every downtown areas in every city, to the most remote islands in the middle of the Atlantic.”
